body_content.explanation: in an election, the number or percentage of votes needed for important changes to be made, when that number is higher than a normal majority (= the difference in the number of votes between the winning person or group and the one that comes second):
examples: The city council needs a supermajority of eleven votes to pass its budget.
The party was one vote short of a super-majority.
Some countries require a supermajority vote for any tax increases.
The United States Constitution requires a supermajority of two-thirds of both houses of Congress to propose a constitutional amendment.
